title: After Bolton, Pompeo’s Role Grows Larger, and Also More Solitary
text:
WASHINGTON—When Mike Pompeo was confirmed as secretary of state 16 months ago, he was considered the last puzzle piece to President Trump’s overhauled foreign policy team. Now, he’s the last one remaining.

The sudden departure on Tuesday of John Bolton as the president’s national security adviser—a strong personality and unique character even by Trumpian standards—removed one of the last dissenting voices in the West Wing. It also immediately empowered Mr. Pompeo, already one of the longest-tenured and most trusted foreign-policy advisers in the current White House.

Whether he remains is an open question, given such key Republicans as Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell (R., Ky.) have urged him to run for an open Kansas Senate seat, while others are suggesting that now may not be the time to leave.

For now at least, the shift within the administration highlights how Mr. Pompeo remains one of the few senior Trump officials who has maintained strong relationships with the traditional wing of the Republican Party while earning support from the new brand of “America First” conservatives that the president has brought into the party, according to Republican officials and Trump allies.

He has also maintained his own personal political base, organizing monthly dinners around Washington with disparate political factions, including groups of farmers, Republican operatives and strategists, business executives, donors and preachers. Mr. Pompeo has organized similar dinners dating back to his time as a U.S. House lawmaker.

Mr. Bolton’s departure also emboldens Mr. Pompeo to shoulder some of Mr. Trump’s most ambitious and unconventional objectives, including meeting with Iran’s leader with no preconditions and bringing Taliban leaders to Camp David for peace talks.

Mr. Pompeo backed recent efforts by Mr. Trump’s envoy to Afghanistan, Zalmay Khalilzad, to broker a deal, and he “didn’t oppose” talks with the Taliban, people familiar with the matter said. The breaking point for Mr. Bolton’s association with Mr. Trump came in a dispute over the president’s interest in speaking directly to the Taliban.`

“These have been the president’s policies,” Mr. Pompeo told reporters Tuesday. “I don’t think any leader around the world should make any assumption that because some one of us departs, that President Trump’s foreign policy will change in a material way.”

Mr. Pompeo and his expanding foreign policy portfolio will be in the spotlight as world leaders converge on New York later this month for the United Nations General Assembly, where the president potentially could meet with his Iranian counterpart, Hassan Rouhani. Mr. Pompeo said Tuesday that such a meeting was possible.

Another concern is the continuing dispute between U.S. allies Japan and South Korea, and the looming end of a military information-sharing agreement between them.

Mr. Pompeo’s role in denuclearizing North Korea may also face new scrutiny. Pyongyang frequently complained that Mr. Bolton—who had proposed using military force to oust current rulers—was a part of Mr. Trump’s team. Mr. Bolton’s departure removes that talking point for North Korean leader Kim Jong Un and his team.

Mr. Bolton’s involvement with North Korea was Mr. Trump’s first complaint about his former national security adviser when speaking to reporters on Wednesday. The president said it was a “disaster” and among Mr. Bolton’s biggest mistakes to publicly say last year that the administration was considering a “Libya model” for quick disarmament in North Korea.

North Korea immediately denounced the comparison as insulting and “sinister.” The fact that Moammar Gadhafi, Libya’s strongman, was overthrown and killed by rebels in 2011 made the comparison objectionable to Pyongyang.

At the time, Kim Kye Gwan, North Korea’s first vice minister for foreign affairs, referred to the regime’s previous statements about Mr. Bolton, which referred to him as a bloodsucker and human scum, while noting, “We do not hide our feeling of repugnance toward him.”

On Wednesday, Mr. Trump said he didn’t blame North Korea for what its leaders said about Mr. Bolton. “We were set back very badly when John Bolton talked about the Libyan model,” the president said.

The expanding role for Mr. Pompeo continues a familiar path for those around the West Wing, where he has leaned on his own political skills to maintain and deepen his relationship with Mr. Trump.

Former House Speaker John Boehner (R., Ohio), who appointed Mr. Pompeo to the prestigious House intelligence committee as a freshman representative in 2011, said that the Kansan’s chief political skill was that he was from the Midwest.

“People from the Midwest are nice, and that’s the first step in this process,” Mr. Boehner said. “And people respect him: He doesn’t play games with people, or mince words. He’s a bit cautious, but smart about what he says and smart about what he doesn’t say.”

Mr. Pompeo, the president’s first director of the Central Intelligence Agency, continues to be involved in the Mr. Trump’s intelligence briefings, according to people familiar with the briefings, an unusual situation for a sitting secretary of state.

At the CIA, he straddled the line between the agency’s analysts and spies and a president who frequently criticized the intelligence community. Early on, when CIA analysts would complain about Mr. Trump’s remarks, Mr. Pompeo would remind them that the president consistently gave the agency the resources it requested, according to people familiar with his tenure there.

Similarly, he provided an initial boost to morale at the State Department. At his swearing-in ceremony in May 2018, he vowed to bring back the State Department’s swagger. He lifted the hiring freeze imposed by his predecessor and regularly held “Meet With Mike” sessions at embassies to receive bottom-up feedback from staff.

More recently, he was considered by several in the administration to be the de facto defense secretary during a recent period of transition. In June, with the Pentagon still under acting leadership, Mr. Pompeo flew to Tampa, Fla., for meetings with the leadership of U.S. Central Command and U.S. Special Operations Command, which are under the purview of the Defense Department. Mr. Pompeo said his visit was intended to ensure coordination between the departments of State and Defense, but his Pentagon counterpart wasn’t present.

Until Mr. Bolton’s replacement is named, he is likely to pick up duties that would normally fall to the national security adviser, according to administration officials and people close to Mr. Pompeo. Only one man in U.S. history, Henry Kissinger, has formally held both titles.

The moment also created an inflection point for Mr. Pompeo, who is being pushed by some Senate Republicans to run for the U.S. Senate seat in Kansas.

That option would provide an exit ramp from the Trump administration amid public polls that raise questions about whether the president will win a second term. Seven of 10 Kansas Republican primary voters hold favorable views of Mr. Pompeo, well above other contenders for the seat, according to a poll conducted June 3-6 by the Club for Growth, a conservative advocacy group.

Josh Holmes, Mr. McConnell’s former chief of staff, said Mr. Trump’s agenda for a potential second term could depend on holding the Kansas Senate seat. “Mike Pompeo can solve that problem instantaneously,” he said.

But Mr. Pompeo is now getting pressure from other Senate Republicans and Trump allies to forgo that campaign and stay by Mr. Trump’s side as the president’s “America First” foreign policy continues to be challenged from China to Iran to Venezuela.

Sen. James Inhofe (R., Okla.) said that Mr. Pompeo “ought to stay where he is” at the State Department.

“He’s one of the last well-informed individuals, kind of the old school,” Mr. Inhofe said. “And I’d prefer that he stay.”

Mr. Trump has said he plans to name a replacement for Mr. Bolton next week, but Mr. Inhofe said the process may take longer. In the interim, he expects the president to lean even more on Mr. Pompeo.

“In the meantime, we have to run this,” he said. Mr. Pompeo, Mr. Inhofe said, “is the most logical person to have that continuity to do it. But let’s wait and see what the president’s decision is.”

Charles Kupchan, a senior National Security Council staffer in the Clinton and Obama administrations, said Mr. Bolton’s departure strengthens Mr. Pompeo’s position, as it removes a key rival for influence.

“Pompeo now has no one in the White House who is an influential figure, a cabinet-level figure, that can stand up to him or go around him,” Mr. Kupchan said.

—Lindsay Wise, Jessica Donati and Vivian Salama contributed to this article.
